##  {background-color="#34605f"}

## Histogram


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|2"}
ggplot(data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm)) + 
  geom_histogram() +
  labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](intro-R-ggplot-import_files/figure-revealjs/hist-1.png){fig-align='center' width=480}
:::
:::


## 

::: columns
::: {.column width="50"}
### Pros

-   Easy to inspect
-   Higher bars represent where data are relatively more common
-   Inspect shape of a distribution (skewed or symmetric)
-   Identify modes
:::

::: {.column width="50"}
### Cons

-   **Do not** plot raw data, plot summaries (counts) of the data!
-   Sensitive to `binwidth`
:::
:::

## Side-by-Side Boxplots {.scrollable}

::: columns
::: {.column width="50"}

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm,
                     x = species)) +
  geom_boxplot() + 
  labs(x = "Penguin Species", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)")
```

## Faceted Histograms


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|4"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 3) +
  facet_wrap(~ species) +
  labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)", 
       title = "Frequency of Captured Penguins by Species", 
       y = "")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](intro-R-ggplot-import_files/figure-revealjs/facet-hist-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768}
:::
:::


## Scatterplots


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|3"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm, x = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](intro-R-ggplot-import_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576}
:::
:::


##  {background-color="#34605f"}

::: {style="margin-top: 100px; font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Multivariate Plots
:::

::: {style="color: #000000; font-size: 0.75em;"}
There are two main methods for adding a third (or fourth) variable into a data visualization:

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Colors**

-   creates colors for every level of a categorical variable
-   creates a gradient for different values of a quantitative variable
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Facets**

-   creates subplots for every level of a variable
-   labels each sub-plot with the value of the variable
:::
:::
:::

## Colors in Scatterplots


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|4,9"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm,
                     x = bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)
       ) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)", 
       color = "Penguin Species")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](intro-R-ggplot-import_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-color-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576}
:::
:::


## Colors in Boxplots


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|4,9"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm,
                     x = species,
                     color = sex)
       ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(x = "Penguin Species", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)", 
       color = "Sex")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](intro-R-ggplot-import_files/figure-revealjs/boxplot-color-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576}
:::
:::


## Facets in Scatterplots


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|6"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm,
                     x = bill_depth_mm,
                     color = sex)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~ species) + 
  labs(x = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)", 
       color = "Sex")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](intro-R-ggplot-import_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-facets-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768}
:::
:::


## Facets in Boxplots


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|6"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm,
                     y = species,
                     fill = sex)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.3) +
  facet_wrap(~ island) + 
  labs(x = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)", 
       fill = "Sex")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](intro-R-ggplot-import_files/figure-revealjs/boxplot-facets-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768}
:::
:::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
